header.h1: Short-Term Residential Load Forecasting Using 2-Step SARIMAX
header.p:
Journal of Electrical Engineering & Technology
(
2021
)

Accesses

div.p: In contrast to city-level and larger aggregate-level load forecasting, load forecasting for residential customers is a much more challenging problem because residential loads are much more volatile. In order to forecast the residential load at one-hour interval 24-h loads the day before, a 2-Step SARIMAX method for residential load forecasting is proposed in this study. The forecasting performance of the proposed method is compared with the existing forecasting methods including SARIMA.

In 2020, South Korea’s residential electricity demand accounted for 14 percent of the total electricity demand [
1
]. Owing to the significant proportion of the total electricity energy demand, the Korean government is pushing to shift electricity supply policy to demand management-oriented policy [
2
]. Advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), an intelligent meter reading system, that makes it easier to measure and collect near-real-time residential electricity demand data, is currently being expanded and distributed in Korea as a key foundation for demand management-oriented energy policy shifting. Demand response a is representative demand management-oriented energy policy. Demand response is also a key element of a smart grid system [
3
,
4
,
5
,
6
]. In a residential power distribution system, demand response can be used to manage power supply to users and smooth system loads. Short-term residential load forecasting predicts residential electricity customers’ demand, which provides key information for making decisions in residential demand response. On the one hand, short-term residential electricity demand forecasting can help satisfy residential electricity customers’ electricity demand and forestall the danger of power outages. On the other hand, short-term residential electricity demand forecasting can benefit power companies and residential electricity customers economically. Based on the results of short-term residential electricity forecasting, utilities can establish pricing strategies for residential electricity demand [
5
].

Load forecasting is mainly based on forecasting techniques founded on time series analysis, of which there is a representative seasonal autoregressive integrated moving average (SARIMA) model. Juberias et al. used the above model to present power forecasting at hourly intervals used in real-time control systems, while Jeong et al. [
7
,
8
] used the above model to present the winter and summer maximum power demand algorithm. Elamin and Fukushige[
9
] used the above model to forecast hourly electricity demand with weather variables such as temperature and humidity.

However, the above examples of load forecasting research are mainly focused on load forecasting at the aggregated level, not on load forecasting at the individual household level. When the above prediction techniques are applied to residential load data, there is a disadvantage in that forecasting uncertainty increases due to differences in load patterns over days of the week for residential consumers and volatility components which is the aperiodic part influenced by residential customer’s behavior [
10
]. Several methods have been reported to address this problem. First, clustering techniques are used to group residential customers, days, or weather to reduce the variance of volatility components within each cluster [
11
,
12
,
13
]. Second, pre-processing techniques, especially spectral analysis techniques such as wavelet analysis, Fourier transform, and empirical mode decomposition (EMD) are used to separate the residential customers’ regular patterns from the volatility components [
14
,
15
,
16
]. The existing methods above are indirect, which aim to avoid volatility components by reducing or separating the volatility component. The proposed 2-Step SARIMAX method is designed to directly learn volatility components by using load data from a group of other households with a similar load patterns to that of the targeted household to be forecasted. Most of the load forecasting methods consider weather information such as temperature in addition to the past load data of residential customer [
17
]. In this paper, the 2-Step SARIMAX method is proposed to predict the load of the targeted residential customer incorporating the load data of other residential customers with a similar load pattern. The 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm does not use only the electricity demand data of residential electricity customer who is the target of the forecasting or use weather factor as an exogenous variable with the above data. The proposed 2-Step SARIMAX method in this paper is designed to use the load data of similar residential customers as exogenous variables. Also, the clustering method using extreme points is developed in the previous study to obtain residential customers with a similar load pattern to that of the targeted residential customer. The proposed method is not only expected to improve the overall residential load forecasting error but it can also reduce the variance of the forecasting errors.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Sect.
2
, the seasonal autoregressive integrated moving average with exogenous variable (SARIMAX), the theory used in the algorithm proposed in this paper, is explained, and the Box Jenkins method, a general procedure that can be applied to an ARIMA-based model is, briefly introduced. Section
3
introduces the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm proposed in this study. In Sect.
4
, the procedure for completing the 2-Step SARIMAX model and the process of forecasting the residential electricity demand are explained in detail, through demonstration. Subsequently, the results are presented. The final section summarizes the results of this study and concludes the thesis with some future research directions.

This section describes the SARIMAX model and clustering method adopted in the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm proposed in this paper, and briefly introduces the Box Jenkins method, a general procedure that can be applied to an ARIMA-based model.

is the time series data, d is the number of differences,
\({\phi }_{p}\)
is the autoregression coefficient,
\({\theta }_{q}\)
is the moving average coefficient,
\({\varepsilon }_{t}\)
is the white noise series or error term following a normal distribution with a constant variance and zero mean and B stands for the backward shift operator.

where
\({B}^{s}\)
is the seasonal backward potential operator, D is the number of seasonal differences,
\({\Phi }_{P}\)
is the seasonal autoregression coefficient,
\({\Theta }_{Q}\)
is the seasonal moving average coefficient, and S is the seasonal period. Finally, the SARIMA model uses non-seasonal AR orders (p), MA orders (q), differences counts (d), seasonal AR orders (P), seasonal MA orders (Q), and seasonal difference counts (D). It can be expressed as SARIMA(p, d, q)
\({(P,D,Q)}_{s}\)
[
7
].

The SARIMAX model is a time series model that additionally considers exogenous variables in the SARIMA model, (the seasonal ARIMA model described above). A model considering the exogenous variable
\({X}_{t}\)
can be represented by the following equation when the mean of the time series data
\({y}_{t}\)
is zero [
19
]:

div.span: $$\begin{aligned} & {\Phi }_{P} \left( {B^{s} } \right)\phi_{p} \left( B \right)\left( {1 - B^{s} } \right)^{D} \left( {1 - B} \right)^{d} y_{t} \\ & \quad = {\Theta }_{Q} \left( {B^{s} } \right)\theta_{q} \left( B \right)\varepsilon_{t} + \gamma X_{t} \\ \end{aligned}$$

div.p:
where
\(\gamma\)
is the parameter of the exogenous variable
\({X}_{t}\)
, and the rest of the symbols are the same as in Eq. (
2
); however, depending on which exogenous variable is selected, it can have a significant effect on describing the time series[
19
].

The Box Jenkins method is illustrated in Fig.
1
. Through the model discrimination and estimation steps, various order values of the time series model are determined, and forecasting for a new period is performed through the remaining procedures [
20
].
Box–Jenkins Method
The clustering method for residential customer using extreme points is adopted to perform grouping the load profiles of residential customers.

The clustering method for residential customer using extreme points uses the local extreme points as shown above Fig.
2
which are effective in analyzing the differences in energy consumption over a period of time between customers. Three features which represent the demographic characteristics of residential customers well are selected in the previous research [
21
]. The features are
\({P}_{2}\)
,
\({P}_{3}\)
and
\({P}_{4}\)
.
\({P}_{2}\)
is the local maximum point value that appears first,
\({P}_{3}\)
is the local minimum point value and
\({P}_{4}\)
is the difference between the two local maximum point values. After selecting features, this method uses the K-means algorithm which is the most utilized clustering algorithm [
22
].
Load profile of Arbitrary residential customer

The process of the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm suitable for the 24-h residential electricity demand forecasting presented in this paper is shown in Fig.
3
.
Flowchart of proposed 2-Step SARIMAX method

First, the specific customer is determined to which the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm will be applied and the target date for electricity demand forecasting. Then, before proceeding with the 2-Step procedure, we proceed with the 1-Step procedure to output the necessary input data when performing the 2-Step procedure. There are two input data outputs from the 1-Step procedure. The first is the exogenous variable training data required when creating the 2-Step SARIMAX model, and the second is the exogenous variable input data required for forecasting after creating the 2-Step SARIMA model.

First, households with an electricity demand pattern similar to that of the residential customer to be forecasted are output using clustering using extreme points and demographic characteristics [
21
]. Then, the electricity demand data of one-hour intervals before the forecast date for households with similar electricity demand patterns are averaged over time to create a single electricity demand data. Train data of exogenous variable is created by collecting the electricity demand data in chronological order by day of the week prior to the targeted forecasting date, as shown in Fig.
4
, and then only the data corresponding to the targeted forecasting date are classified. Due to smoothing effect, the forecasting error for a group of similar residential customer loads in the 1-Step is usually much smaller compared to the load of a single residential customer.
Classifying data by day of the week processing
The main steps of the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm are as follows:

li.p: Identify the targeted residential customer and targeted date to be predicted.
Select residential customers with a similar load pattern to that of the targeted residential customer using the clustering method with extreme points.
Compute the average load of the selected similar residential customers.
Classify the exogenous variable data to obtain training dataset according to that of the day of week corresponding to the targeted date.
Apply the Box Jenkins method with the exogenous variable data to obtain one-step SARIMA model.
Estimate exogenous variable data for the targeted date using one-step SARIMA model.
Obtain time series data for training dataset by classifying the load data of the targeted residential customer that matches the day of the week corresponding to the targeted date.
Apply the Box Jenkins method with the exogenous variable data and time-series data to build two-step SARIMAX model.
Forecast load at an hourly interval of 24 h on the targeted data using the two-step SARIMAX model.

div.p:
In this Sect.
4
, the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm was applied hourly residential electricity demand data of 188 households from May 2018 to April 2019. The proposed algorithm was used to forecast the one-hour interval electricity demand for targeted household from April 1, 2019 to April 30, 2019. The mean absolute error (MAE) was calculated to show performance of the load forecasting. For the comparison of accuracy performance, a simple SARIMA model, SARIMAX using weather element and daily SARIMA algorithm were applied to the same data. The MAE of models are all shown in Table
1
.

figcaption.b: Table 1 Comparison of average values of MAE

div.p: First, one of the 188 residential electricity customers was selected as the targeted. In addition, as described above, the electricity demand of targeted residential electricity customer from April 1, 2019 to April 30, 2019 at hourly intervals was forecasted. The first targeted forecasting date was April 1, 2019.

After determining the targeted residential customer and forecasting date, the 1-Step procedure was carried out as described in Sect.
3
. First, using the clustering method for residential customer with extreme points, residential electricity customers with similar electricity demand patterns to that of the targeted residential electricity customer were selected [
21
]. The optimal number of groups was 6, with a total of 38 households selected. Then, the selected residential electricity customers’ electricity demand data at an hourly interval before the targeted forecasting date were averaged by date and time to create representative electricity demand data. The representative electricity demand data and the electricity demand data of the targeted residential electricity customer were averaged by hourly time. The two hourly electricity demand data patterns are shown for 24 h, as shown in Fig.
5
. It can be seen that the two electricity demand data patterns are similar.
Hourly load patterns

The representative electricity demand data obtained is classified into seven types of electricity demand data for each day of the week, as shown in Fig.
4
, according to the flowchart in Fig.
3
. One of the same days as the targeted forecasting date of seven types of electricity demand data for each day of the week was adopted as the train data of exogenous variable. The first targeted forecasting date, April 1, 2019 is Monday, thereby after adopting the Monday electricity demand data as train data of exogenous variable among seven types of electricity demand data, a 1-Step SARIMA was created by applying the Box Jenkins method. Then, the input data of exogenous variable to be used in 2-Step SARIMAX was forecasted using 1-Step SARIMA. 1-Step procedure is first described in detail as follows.

First, as shown in the first graph of Fig.
6
, it was confirmed that train data of exogenous variable was not stationary. The first difference was then applied to obtain stationarity, as shown in the second graph in Fig.
6
.
Plot of raw data and differential data

After obtaining stationarity, autocorrelation function (ACF) and partial autocorrelation function (PACF) graphs were shown in Fig.
7
, to infer the q-value, which is the order related to the moving average (MA), and the p-value, which is the order related to autoregression (AR).
ACF and PACF of differential data

Subsequently, seasonal differences were performed after checking the seasonality of the data, and seasonal autocorrelation function (SACF) and seasonal partial autocorrelation function (SPACF) graphs were drawn, as shown in Fig.
8
, to infer the orders Q and P. Additionally, focusing on the repetition of the cycle every 24 h, s was determined to be 24.
ACF and PACF of seasonal differential data

The procedure for inferring p, q, P, and Q by eliciting Figs.
7
and
8
is not a definitive method for determining each order value, but rather a procedure for determining candidates for an appropriate order value. Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), the parameter selection criterion for the SARIMA model, is effective when the number of samples is high, as in this study, and thus can be a suitable reference value [
23
]. Therefore, in the process of the Box Jenkins method, all BIC values were calculated for the model designated as a combination of candidate values of p, q, P, Q, and the 1-Step SARIMA was created by selecting the model’s parameters with the smallest BIC value. Then, the 2-Step SARIMAX’s input data of exogenous variable was forecasted.

After the 1-Step procedure, which outputs the two data necessary for the 2-Step procedure, the 2-Step procedure was followed. First, the electricity demand data at one-hour intervals for the targeted residential electricity customer was classified into seven types of electricity demand data for each day of the week as shown in Fig.
4
. Among the seven data sets, the electricity demand data on Monday was adopted as the time series data for training. The reason for classifying data by day in the above 1-Step procedure and 2-Step procedure can be seen in Fig.

. As shown in the figure below, the patterns of electricity demand for residential electricity customers by day of the week, especially during the weekdays and weekend, are distinctly different.
Average electricity load at hourly interval

A 2-Step SARIMAX is created by applying the Box Jenkins method to the adopted time series data for training and the train data of exogenous variable generated through 1-Step procedure. The specific process is the same as applying the Box Jenkins method in the 1-Step procedure above. Subsequently, ACF, PACF, SACF, and PACF graphs were used to determine candidates for the appropriate parameters of 2-Step SARIMAX. As in creating the 1-Step SARIMA model, s is equal to 24, and then all BIC values are calculated for the model designated as a combination of p, q, P, and Q candidate values using train data of exogenous variable and time series data for training. Then, the model with the smallest BIC value was selected to generate the 2-Step SARIMAX. By inputting the forecasted input data of exogenous variable to the generated 2-Step SARIMAX the electricity demand of residential electricity customer targeted for forecasting for 24 h at an hourly interval of April 1, 2019 is forecasted. Using the same procedure, the electricity demand data for 24 h at hourly intervals from April 1 to April 30, 2019 were forecasted and compared with the actual data using MAE.

The temperature of the residential area of the residential customer is used as an exogenous variable in the SARIMAX with weather factor model. The results of the case studies show that the proposed two-step SARIMAX method not only improves the overall residential load forecasting error but also reduces the variance of the forecasting errors.

Short-term residential load forecasting can provide key information for residential demand response operation by predicting the demand of residential customers in the near future. In this research, a study was conducted to forecast short-term residential load at 1-h intervals for a day. Using the SARIMA model, which is considered as the most basic time series analysis model, the daily SARIMA algorithm proposed in the previous paper, the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm proposed in this paper, and the SARIMA with weather factor model, the electricity demand of residential electricity customers targeted for forecasting at one-hour intervals for a month is forecasted.

The MAE for each day was calculated and averaged to evaluate the performance of each model. The 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm performed better than the other three models. There are two reasons for this excellent performance. The first reason is that the electricity demand pattern of residential electricity customers has a different pattern for each day of the week, and this is reflected in the process in the 2-Step SARIMAX algorithm. Second, the average value of electricity demand of other residential electricity customers with electricity demand patterns similar to those of targeted residential electricity customers was introduced as an exogenous variable and reflected in the model. Also, the average electricity demand of households selected using the clustering method and the electricity demand pattern of the household targeted for forecasting were similar. The proposed method effectively reflected the electricity demand characteristics of residential electricity customers and achieved better forecasting performance than existing methods.

Using the proposed method in this paper, the forecasting of electricity demand of a residential customer was performed and better performance was shown. A study that can further improve the forecasting performance in several aspects is needed. First, the proposed method in this paper has a lower forecasting performance compared to other days of the week in the case of Saturday of the weekend. This is because the current method proposed in this paper does not fully reflect the electricity demand patterns of residential electricity customers during the weekend. This is expected to improve forecasting performance by applying the recently popular machine learning methods, more sophisticated regression models, and multivariate time series models. In addition, in this study, special days were not considered; however, it is recognized that a study on forecasting method suitable for the characteristics of special days is necessary.
